212578: A Display of My Dark Power.author: DarthParallax
212578: A Display of My Dark Power.text_parsed:
I have an idea for a Loyalty ability on a Super Villain Planeswalker that is like this, except does not force you to screw yourself:

+4: Destroy target land. That land's controller adds three mana in any combination of colors to his or her mana pool.

This would be risky, but worth it, to play targeting either your own or your opponents' lands. Especially if your opponents happen to be low on cards, or you played a mana-leak. That extra mana is not guaranteed to be helpful to them. But since it sometimes would give them a free spell, it's ok that it turns all your lands into Black Lotuses. >:) A two-sided sword still, but one not as guaranteed to favor the opponents as this scheme, whose creative value outweighs its Development sharpness by a considerable amount.

So, so, so much weaker than the good schemes.

Smacking each opponent for 3 is completely irrelevant, and gaining ~10 life is a lot less worthwhile than affecting the board, especially when some of the other schemes you could be playing are so hilariously powerful.

They could have easily have made it 5 life per opponent; I'd still be sad to flip it instead of behold the power of destruction, all in good time, tooth, claw, and tail, into the earthen maw, every last vestige shall rot, which of you burns brightest... the list goes on.

Cool flavor though.

212582: Into the Earthen Maw.author: DarthParallax
212582: Into the Earthen Maw.text_parsed:
This is a catch-all against the DnD Party style of Hero teaming: (by which I mean 'Fill All the Roles': Aggro, Control, and Combo)

The non-flying creature is your Red-Green aggro player's Big Dude

The flying creature is your Blue-White control player's Angel or Sphinx

The graveyard is your Black-X Reanimator combo player's hand.

212585: Behold the Power of Destruction.author: allmighty_abacus
212585: Behold the Power of Destruction.text_parsed:
necromancer arch enemy- I will crush the world of mortals beneath the rotting flesh of the undead! Just as soon as I spend roughly a decade sifting through graveyards dodging the town guard hauling all these foul smelling corpses back to my lair... but it will be so worth it!

dragon lord arch enemy- Thinking is hard. Here, fight this dragon! Haha, Haha haha!

enraged gardener arch enemy- Get off my lawn! Giant man-eating plants! Spontaneous eruptions of land! I'm not entirely sure why I took up arching in the first place!

Artificer arch enemy- Tsk tsk. You call those schemes? let me tell you about a scheme. I'm going to put a GIANT LASER. On an IMPENETRABLE FORTRESS. That FLIES. Also I invented flying buildings. And the laser. I'm going to blow those so-called defenders of righteousness back to the stone age.

enraged gardener arch enemy- Well I invented an economically safe pesticide! It is even produced locally! With domestic products!

Artificer arch enemy- how are you allowed to work with us? How is pesticide remotely villainous?

eraged gardener arch enemy- THE PEST IS HUMANS


Clearly, there is only one real archenemy.

212594: The Iron Guardian Stirs.author: Lyoncet
212594: The Iron Guardian Stirs.text_parsed:
Passable, but situational. I've actually won two games in no small part thanks to this card. Or rather, thanks to turn 1 The Iron Guardian Stirs, turn two The Iron Guardian Stirs, turn three I Know All, I See All. (Yes, that happened twice. Two games apart.) Still, Look Skyward and Despair is quite a bit better in most situations because of the evasion and the 4-turn clock as opposed to 5 turns.

Since this is from the Esper-themed Archenemy deck, I appreciate how very blue the flavor text sounds. For all white's self-righteousness and black's malevolence, you just can't beat good old mocking, sneering, blue hubris.

212606: May Civilization Collapse.author: sarroth
212606: May Civilization Collapse.text_parsed:
Early enough in the game this could be devastating; however, too conditional to be worth playing.

I like choose self or others, but only if you couldn't choose others if you're the only one remaining. I don't know why they made it so you could, as it just doesn't make sense. Solution? Don't play that way. Even then, this will still be iffy if you only have 2 opponents, as choosing Others won't be as powerful as Self in that instance, but it'd certainly help to make the concept work better.

212611: My Crushing Masterstroke.author: Lyoncet
212611: My Crushing Masterstroke.text_parsed:
I pulled this once when my only remaining opponents were a blue strict permission deck and a near-dead black discard deck with no remaining board presence. "Ha! I have your Rhystic Study! And it has haste! What are you gonna do about it?"

Like most board-affecting schemes, big potential to whiff if pulled early or against the wrong decks. But in the right situation well any scheme that gets better and better the stronger your opponents' position is has my support.

212611: My Crushing Masterstroke.author: DarthParallax
212611: My Crushing Masterstroke.text_parsed:
Actually, it seems that Archenemy is somewhat like the Chess Variant where you give the Black Queen the additional powers of the Knight and sic her against the whole White Army on her own.

Which is to say, it has nearly been solved. The White Pieces are supposed to always win unless you are a particularly brilliant Queen-player AND you are distinctly better than your opponent.

Magic has infinitely more different possible matchups than Chess, but I can hardly imagine, out of 3 Hero decks, not a single control player, and if one Blue-Black mage dedicates their game plan to pure sabotage, the other two players will not have much trouble beating you up. or you can all play Blue like douchebags and Archenemy feels like the nerd on the playground against the Bully Gang. :p
This kind of card is needed to legitimize the point of even trying to play as the Archenemy.

If I had an Archenemy Playgroup, I would always advise the Heroes to 'think DnD'-- which is to say Fill All the Roles--One Elf Guy to get us lands with Collective Voyage and do dumb stuff with Lotus Cobra; one out-and-out Control Wizard running Jace, the Mind Sculptor and Force of Will and other fun stuff like that, and 3rd guy can be Red-White-Black Kaalia EDH, fighting an Archenemy with another Archenemy, giving us our own Mass Damage, Wrath The Everything, and Combo Wins From Nowhere moments. A very nice use of all 5 colors and creating a diverse team that allows for good role-playing on top.
That's if I wanted to make a Hero Party to slay any Dragon, solve any Sphinx, banish any Demon...oh you get point. win all the time.

If I wanted to design some give-and-take to keep things fun, though....

Advice for balancing out the basic premise of the format: Set 1 Archenemy EDH deck against 2 normal decks and an EDH deck. Try also using some sort of color restrictions on the team to enforce diversity to prevent the 'Too much Red' or 'Too much Blue' problems.
Also consider banning the Heroes from playing Black.

Basically, if the Good Guys play like Bad Guys, (which most of them will unfortunately want to do) there is no way the Archenemy has a chance. :p

212614: I Bask in Your Silent Awe.author: JaxsonBateman
212614: I Bask in Your Silent Awe.text_parsed:
@Idiosynch - I think you are misunderstanding, as many people have (including myself). If an ongoing scheme (or schemes) are in play, you still reveal a new scheme each turn and use its abilities. The ongoing one stays around until its abandoned, in addition to the new scheme you reveal each turn.

This scheme still isn't all that powerful - it might slow down your opponent a little, and hoses things like storm, cascade and Vengevine, but given how powerful some of the other schemes are it probably doesn't deserve a slot.

212618: Your Fate Is Thrice Sealed.author: voyager1
212618: Your Fate Is Thrice Sealed.text_parsed: In my experience with Archenemy, this has proven to easily be one of the most beneficial schemes. It's not as flashy as some of the other schemes, but it never fails to put you in a better position than you were at in the beginning of the turn -- card draw and mana production are pretty fundamental to the game, so it's hard to go wrong with more of both. And if you're lucky enough to hit two lands off the top of your library, it's better acceleration than Realms Befitting My Majesty.

212619: I Call on the Ancient Magics.author: mutantman
212619: I Call on the Ancient Magics.text_parsed: The trouble here is that your opponent gets to fetch a free Magister Sphinx or something to screw you over, so the only way to get good use out of this scheme is if you're pulling out combo pieces that make you win right there, in which case, that's kinda lame.
212619: I Call on the Ancient Magics.text_posted: The trouble here is that your opponent gets to fetch a free Magister Sphinx or something to screw you over, so the only way to get good use out of this scheme is if you're pulling out combo pieces that make you win right there, in which case, that's kinda lame.

212619: I Call on the Ancient Magics.author: Lyoncet
212619: I Call on the Ancient Magics.text_parsed:
Very risky scheme, since as pointed out it's really only that great if you're down to 1 opponent OR if you're getting combo pieces but since you can't control when it comes down, and your opponents are also liable to search out combo pieces (just one per, but that may be all they need), you better make damn sure you can win when this flips. Which, as I said, you can't, because it's randomized.

Still, of the "may hurt you more than it helps you" Schemes, it's probably one of the better ones. And it can certainly be good if played in the right deck; tutoring out two cards before your pre-combat main phase for no mana investment can end the game easily assuming you've had enough turns to get a little mana on the table. And your opponents won't get any use out of those cards if they're, you know, a pile of goo.

212619: I Call on the Ancient Magics.author: DarthParallax
212619: I Call on the Ancient Magics.text_parsed:
This card reads: Get the Heroes to thank you for destroying the best cards in their deck. Not necesarily in that order. >:D


This card would be relatively unimpressive compared to a simple Diabolic (let alone Demonic) Tutor, if it weren't for the crucial unevenness of information!

Don't think of this as a 'real' tutor--real tutor's get you card quality and sometimes even card advantage. Three heroes that are going into a Fortress KNOWING you are an evil bastard out to kill them and you give them each a tutor? they WILL get more and better cards than you.

Rofl-lol you sneaky bastard....you WANT this to happen!!!!

You get see what they get, and you know whether or not you need to search out Wrath of God, or Counterspell, or Mind Shatter. Maybe you just need a good ol' fashioned Disk. This is the Next Level of Painful choice cards-- if they get 'bad' stuff, knowing you are trying to draw out their champions, then you can get something that's just bigger and meaner. If they get good stuff, you can sabotage them. If they read this comment, they won't know which you'll do and they'll cry at the stress- and if they don't, they'll fall right into your trap anyway.

This is the most Evil Deathtrap in Magic. And it comes, like all good deathtraps, wrapped like a PRESENT for them!

You are peeking through time. Spying the Future, then counterplanning against it. This is the moment the villain spies on the heroes, and they don't know he's there.

You want them to get their very best goodies out NOW, force their hand, then Open the Black Gates!
Then Counterspell them. Like A Boss.


Once you realize what you can really do with this card, and your opponents realize you realize what you can do with this card, THEN they will be too terrified that you will silver-bullet their pets to stop you.....


from fetching your combo pieces.


MAN, I love being EVIL!!!!!!!!

212648: All in Good Time.author: Bazooka99
212648: All in Good Time.text_parsed:
I think people overrate this card somewhat. In a typical Archenemy game of 1 vs. 3, the one player gets 1 bonus card draw and 20 extra life at the start of the game (obviously). Aside from those two advantages, the Scheme deck is supposed to make up for the disadvantage of having 2 additional players against you. Simply taking an extra turn only does you so much good when your opponents have 3 turns or more.

Certainly a good card, but far from overpowered. A free Time Warp is not nearly as good as the free Insurrection provided by My Crushing Masterstroke, or the free Violent Ultimatum provided by Tooth, Claw, and Nail.

HA! Tooling with my old comment on this card, I finally figured out why some comments italicize/bold/underline the rest of the page! It's if you autocard within the text modification. (If you leave the italics/bold/underline bracket open, it doesn't let you post.) Ahem. Anyways...

(And now it's back to being all italicized. Just can't catch a break it seems. /sigh)


I would just like to point out that I'm pretty sure this card is currently the highest rated card on Gatherer. Badlands comes up first if you search non-special cards by descending community rating, and it's currently rated at 4.980. This is currently 4.983 (edit: now 4.986). So yeah, that's pretty good.

@Bazooka99
"I think people overrate this card somewhat. In a typical Archenemy game of 1 vs. 3, the one player gets 1 bonus card draw and 20 extra life at the start of the game (obviously). Aside from those two advantages, the Scheme deck is supposed to make up for the disadvantage of having 2 additional players against you. Simply taking an extra turn only does you so much good when your opponents have 3 turns or more.

"Certainly a good card, but far from overpowered. A free Time Warp is not nearly as good as the free Insurrection provided by My Crushing Masterstroke, or the free Violent Ultimatum provided by Tooth, Claw, and Nail."

I disagree. Yeah, there are times when one of those cards will help you more than this would help you. But while both of those effects may (and that's a big "may") help you more in the right scenario, this one has the biggest advantage any scheme card can dream for: it's as good on turn 1 as on turn 10, and just as good no matter what the board looks like. If you get My Crushing Masterstroke when the Heroes all have 2+ creatures down, it's likely better. But if 1) one (or more) of your opponents is playing a creature-light deck (very likely since control seems to be great against Archenemies) or 2) it's still early in the game and your opponents all have one 1/2 creature out, it may as well be A Display of my Dark Power. And if you have a strong enough board position - again, very likely in Archenemy - two attacks with all of your creatures against a (possibly tapped out) opponent could be much more powerful than one attack against each opponent with their own creatures plus one attack with all of yours.

Since you have no control over when you play them, the most important thing in a Scheme card is flexibility. Many schemes with great effects can end up being completely useless if you draw them at the wrong time. So while yeah, at turn 8 against a bunch of creature-heavy decks I'd rather draw My Crushing Masterstroke, the fact that at best it will give me a slight advantage over All in Good Time and at worst will do literally nothing tips my favor towards this one.

That's not to say that Tooth, Claw, and Tail or My Crushing Masterstroke are poor Schemes. But as it seems like you're ignoring the single most important trait a Scheme can have in your analysis, so I find it very lacking.

220451: Chameleon Colossus.author: 2pcsofcandy
220451: Chameleon Colossus.text_parsed:
Just had a huge Timmy moment with this card today. Pulled off Nissa Revane's ultimate with a fully leveled Joraga Treespeaker out and swung with this for somewhere in the ballpark of 10,000,000+ damage.

As for the card itself, it's one of the better changelings, I think. The protection from black does seem random, but it's better than having no sort of evasion whatsoever or eating a Doom Blade or Go for the Throat. Being nothing more than a dude with the potential to get huge holds back so many other cards that look and have every right to be awesome (like this guy's buddy Taurean Mauler who had so much hype when he was spoiled and then just kinda fell flat or Mold Adder). So the pro-black really pushes this over the top into awesome territory.

220452: Fertilid.author: kl2789
220452: Fertilid.text_parsed:
pretty dece blue-green mill deck using this. load up on this, archive traps and trapmakers snares and you've got one hell of a combo; if you have fertilid in play and manage to pull out all four archive traps into your hand with the snares, then you can just hit them with fertilid's activated ability to force them to search and BAM! all four traps for 0 mana, mill for 52 in one turn.

only downside is the amount of turns it might take to pull out all the cards you need. not to mention those anti-mill cards like ulamog, elixir and blightsteel; although, if you're feeling pretty ballsy, you can also load up on leyline of the void and hope you pull one (maybe two) in your starting hand so you can play them for no cost. that would deal with the blights and ulamogs pretty easily. and if you're smart, you can always counter an elixir before it ever hits the field. but then that just gets really confusing, with all the things you're trying to do at the same time.

still, seeing a combo like that would be pretty intense.

A very nice card, in my opinion. Your opponents are left with the choice of either spending something to get rid of it/shut it down, or letting it grow into an absolute monster.

And even if they do something that leaves it just sitting on the field staring around like an idiot (like the "can't attack/block" or "doesn't untap" Auras), you can always use it to fuel a spell like Fling. There's nothing quite like killing someone by throwing a cow made of Jello at them.

Relevant creature type, relevant ability, and fair casting cost. Wow, back in the days of no Mythic magic, who wudda thunk it? Seriously I love this guy. Played him in standard and I always like it when my opponent didnt want to play spells for fear of pumping him up. Usually this would stall them from playing their weenies. They knew playing a 2/2 of their own meant mine would be a 3/3 so they kept waiting to draw a removal spell.

Cards like this need to be printed more often. And its a red card, I can already see it being a green card with the growth ability, but Red actually got a decent strategic card. Wow!

220455: Branching Bolt.author: Krispyz
220455: Branching Bolt.text_parsed: Question: Say you were to choose to target two creatures. If one of them then becomes an invalid target (say the opponent gives one of the creatures pro-red at instant speed), does that counter the entire spell or would the other target still be affected? I'm curious if, when you choose the "and" clause, it can no longer go back to "or" or not.
220455: Branching Bolt.text_posted: Question: Say you were to choose to target two creatures. If one of them then becomes an invalid target (say the opponent gives one of the creatures pro-red at instant speed), does that counter the entire spell or would the other target still be affected? I'm curious if, when you choose the "and" clause, it can no longer go back to "or" or not.

220455: Branching Bolt.author: NoobOfLore
220455: Branching Bolt.text_parsed: A spell with multiple targets will only fizzle if NONE of the targets are valid at the time of resolution. So if you choose "and," it won't "go back to or," if something makes a target invalid, but it will still hit all valid targets remaining.
220455: Branching Bolt.text_posted: A spell with multiple targets will only fizzle if NONE of the targets are valid at the time of resolution. So if you choose "and," it won't "go back to or," if something makes a target invalid, but it will still hit all valid targets remaining.

220457: Dregscape Zombie.author: Mode
220457: Dregscape Zombie.text_parsed:
"Can you Cloudshift this after unearthing and attacking to keep it from being exiled?" --Araganor

Unfortunately not.
Unearth's replacement effect is quite a buzzkill regarding such combos. Once you unearth a creature, you have to "exile it (...) if it would leave the battlefield", which means this happens instead of anything else.

Cloudshift triggers this effect (exiling the zombie), so Cloudshift's ability can't do anything. Similarly, it's just exiled right from the battlefield if it would die, preventing any abilities that would trigger on stuff being put into your graveyard.

That's why I am not a big fan of Unearth. I wish Wizard had worded it differently.
Because it would have been possible to prevent easy abuse without prohibiting any shenanigans like this.
Imagine this wording for example, which has been inspired by Evoke:

Unearth (You may cast this spell from your graveyard for its unearth cost. If you do, sacrifice it at the beginning of the next end step. It gains haste. When it is put into a graveyard, exile it.)

220457: Dregscape Zombie.author: The_Stray
220457: Dregscape Zombie.text_parsed:
Actually...yes, you CAN Cloudshift it. Take a look at this ruiling:

If a creature returned to the battlefield with unearth would leave the battlefield for any reason, it's exiled instead -- unless the spell or ability that's causing the creature to leave the battlefield is actually trying to exile it! In that case, it succeeds at exiling it. If it later returns the creature card to the battlefield (as Oblivion Ring or Flickerwisp might, for example), the creature card will return to the battlefield as a new object with no relation to its previous existence. The unearth effect will no longer apply to it.

This same trick is in Standard right now with Whip of Erebos and Obzedat, Ghost Council
220457: Dregscape Zombie.text_posted:

220461: Obelisk of Esper.author: majinara
220461: Obelisk of Esper.text_parsed:
@ Clockwork Well, there are in most cases worse than the ingot. There are rare exceptions. For example if your opponent needs another red mana to be able to play his winning card. If he manages to steal your ingot, he will have that red mana. If he steals the obelisk: nope.
Or lets say your opponent has a hoard-smelter dragon. If you have an ingot in play, your opponent can keep activating the dragon on the ingot as often as he wants (if he has enough mana) since the ingot won't be destroyed, dealing a huge amount of damage to you. An obelisk wouldn't allow more than one activation. :)

In any case, I prefer to fetch lands from my library.

220472: Two-Headed Dragon.author: Swag_Crow
220472: Two-Headed Dragon.text_parsed:
It obviously shouldn't have double strike. Look at the flavor, guys. The two heads attack at the same time, so it can't be blocked by a single creature. If it went one head in front of the other, then it'd be able to be blocked, since there isn't another head attacking in the same turn as it. Get your flavor right, guys.

-Swag_Crow

220480: Sign in Blood.author: AdOutAce
220480: Sign in Blood.text_parsed:
I love the simple, colorful spells like these with drawbacks, because they help get new players from the rudimentary stage to the more nuanced stage of playing Magic, and it's always fun to see the lightbulb go on. I suggested a friend put this very card in a nuts-and-bolts mono-black deck he was building. After about five minutes of hesitant discussion, he says "but then again...the cards I end up drawing have a really high chance of dealing more than 2 damage, or saving me over 2 damage in the future, don't they?"

Kind of a basic grasp on it, but I couldn't have been more proud. You learned your first lesson in card advantage, amigo!
220480: Sign in Blood.text_posted:

220489: Festering Goblin.author: Emmerich
220489: Festering Goblin.text_parsed: Fume Spitter? Ok, I can see how you MIGHT prefer to make a creature smaller for the rest of the game, but with the new combat rules, this card IMO is actually BETTER than Fume Spitter. Fume Spitter has to sacrifice to put the counter on a creature, meaning he isn't doing his combat damage. This guy does his combat damage AND makes a creature smaller until end of turn. He can kill a 1/1 then take out another 1/1, or he can take out a 2/2 all on his own. If you have the mana to cast Lord of the Undead, that means you have the mana to bring him back to hand AND put him back in play. Not to mention at that point he can kill 3/3s. Sorry, but Fume Spitter fails to beat this guy.

220489: Festering Goblin.author: Ferlord
220489: Festering Goblin.text_parsed:
A 1-cost Zombie Goblin that gives creatures -1/-1 when it dies: Is it better than Mogg Fanatic? Well, with the new rules, it technically is. It can also be played in Zombie decks as a viable 1-drop, and that's exactly what I use it for.
I'd go as far to say that Festering is the second-best 1-drop zombie, although he's highly out-classed by Gravecrawler.

Also, it can destroy creatures which are indestructible (as long as their toughness is 1).

Also also, it is possible to conduct shenanigans if you play such spells as Innocent Blood or Demon of Death's Gate: ones that require you to sacrifice your own creatures.


Regardless, I think he is exceptionally versatile. 4.5/5

220489: Festering Goblin.author: El_Pared
220489: Festering Goblin.text_parsed:
easily one of the top 5 best 1 drop zombies, if not the best. I would only concede his spot at number 1 to Gravecrawler maybe, but gravecrawler only gets it for being incredibly hard to keep dead, and if you're playing zombies right, ALL of your creatures are hard to keep dead.

Festering Goblin consistently shows up in my zombie decks. He's almost the perfect zombie. He's cheap, he has a good effect when he dies, and his flavor is text awesome for both a zombie and a goblin. Not to mention that my favorite zombie didn't get nerfed by the Tenth Edition rules changes, but his cousins Mogg Fanatic and (much later of course) Fume Spitter, did.

Overall one of the most solid zombie cards in the game. If you're playing zombies and don't run Festering Goblin, you're doing it wrong

220490: Kamahl, Fist of Krosa.author: Camtos
220490: Kamahl, Fist of Krosa.text_parsed: You do the following: use Kamahl's first ability and target an opponent's land. Then use the Goblin Sharpshooter to destroy it. 220490: Kamahl, Fist of Krosa.author: _X_
220490: Kamahl, Fist of Krosa.text_parsed:
Brilliant mono-green EDH general - garunteed overrun on a stick. With only 11 mana you can cast him from zone and overrun once, 16 to do it twice and 21 to do it 3 times. Putting creatures on board and mana ramping - two things green can do best - now becomes your generals win condition. Tucked safely away in your general zone, Kamahl sits pretty until these conditions are met. As soon as you have creatures on board, available mana and a good chance of limited responses you can kill all your opponents at once. That's how green wins games - OVERRUN STYLE!

5/5

220490: Kamahl, Fist of Krosa.author: Ferlord
220490: Kamahl, Fist of Krosa.text_parsed:
Sweet Jesus

Although this is highly disputable, Kamahl could be considered the best Mono-Green EDH general.

I think anyone who's thought about it before knows why, and anyone who hasn't, well, just read every comment pertaining to him.

So, instead of telling you his abilities, I'm just going to give a few situations where Kamahl simply won me the game.

1 - I was playing against a pal who used Nacatl War-Pride and nothing else. I had about 4 support elves (Rofellos, Llanowar Emissary, Priest of Titania, Llanowar Elves and Fyndhorn Elves), and Kamahl. Suffice to say, his plan was to kill my mana acceleration. Well, when he attacked, I tapped Rofellos and made all of my elves 4/4s; just enough to survive the onslaught of the Nacatl.

2 - Different friend, similar situation: I had a lot of support out (about the same as above, add a few others) and Kamahl out. He was using an Animar deck, and Animar was an 14/14 (thanks to Eldrazi Con***ion and 3 other creatures he played) and he played Chain Reaction, so I'd lose on account of Commander Damage. In response, I made enough of his lands creatures, which not only killed his manabase, but Animar as well.

3 - I played Collective Voyage on turn 8, which in truth, was a poor move on my part. Although I had a whopping 21 forests, on my friend's turn (same one), he wiped the board (Disaster Radius), played Animar + Birds of Paradise + Scuttlemutt + Solemn Simulacrum + Wurmcoil Engine + Primeval Titan, all for 20 mana.
Well, on my turn, I just played Kamahl, and said, "Nice army you've got. Wanna attack? I've got a hidden army right here" pointing to my lands.
He didn't attack.

220496: Llanowar Reborn.author: Henrietta
220496: Llanowar Reborn.text_parsed:
The point of rarities is not necessarily power, as there are many many commons that are far better than many many rares (and even some mythic rares). Rarities exist for two main gameplay reasons - one, simpler cards are common and complex cards are rare (simple cards not necessarily being less powerful than complex cards) so that the casual player who doesn't understand the rules very well sees less complex cards, and two, to control Limited gameplay by changing how often you see certain cards. For example, M10 dual lands aren't necessarily powerful, in fact they're rather average on the dual land power scale, but they're rare so that they don't show up often in drafts or such because they're usually not very useful in draft decks.

Of course, there's also the money reason. When they DO print a good rare, they're worth a lot more than a good common at the same power level, so more people buy packs hoping to find money rares that they can sell for more than a pack is worth. This was showcased at an extreme with Worldwake - with Jace, the Mind Sculptor being over $100 each for a long time. people bought tons of WWK packs hoping to find a Jace the could sell.

For example, M10 dual lands aren't necessarily powerful, in fact they're rather average on the dual land power scale, but they're rare so that they don't show up often in drafts or such because they're usually not very useful in draft decks.

Of course, there's also the money reason. When they DO print a good rare, they're worth a lot more than a good common at the same power level, so more people buy packs hoping to find money rares that they can sell for more than a pack is worth. This was showcased at an extreme with Worldwake - with Jace, the Mind Sculptor being over $100 each for a long time. people bought tons of WWK packs hoping to find a Jace the could sell.

220496: Llanowar Reborn.author: blurrymadness
220496: Llanowar Reborn.text_parsed:
Built a GU proliferation/graft deck for under $10. Still beats the hell out of people.

As a side note I don't think Oran-Rief is more powerful at all. It has to tap to add counters. It's certainly more powerful in a token deck, but if you use proliferate you can get the same effectiveness with yet another land open. Further, it's important to note that Oran-Rief=behind the curve creatures. Yes you're making up for it by adding the counters, but ideally each turn you should be playing the best creature from your deck you can afford and Llanowar Reborn allows you to do that *while still buffing it*. Rief forces you to play a weaker creature and attempt to make up for it by adding a counter.

Besides.. you can run both if you want...

220497: Spin into Myth.author: Lyoncet
220497: Spin into Myth.text_parsed:
I think this card deserves a decent rating, if only because it's bloody blue targeted removal that also messes with dredge or graveyard-based triggered effects, gets around indestructibility, and gives you a more flexible way to deal with non-counterable cards than Mindbreak Trap or Time Stop. Yeah, it's expensive, but unless I'm missing something it's mono-blue's only one-card, targeted, permanent, all-purpose creature removal. You can Icy Prison/Eon Hub something, or Diminish/Prodigal Sorcerer, or Disorient/Twisted Image, but none of those will permanently remove something on their own. (Reality Acid will work if you have the luxury of waiting 3 turns). There's also a few cards like Mind Control, Control Magic, Steal Artifact, and Rootwater Matriarch, but with the prevalence of things like Disenchant and Naturalize, and even Unsummon to fizzle the enchantment at any point, I'd be wary about calling those permanent spot removal.

Yeah, tutor effects, particularly Besieged's crown jewel Green Sun's Zenith, will laugh at this (unless they get countered), but against decks without tutors, this is about as permanent as you get outside exile, and it's in a color that is notoriously bad at permanent spot removal (and hasn't really had one since Unlimited). At the same time, 5 CMC, even if 4 of it is colorless, is pretty hefty even at instant speed, and if a big threat has slipped past your counters, you may not be able to last long enough to deal with it. In any other color, this would be a 2.5-3 or so, but in blue, I'm willing to bump it to 3.5/5.

220498: Armadillo Cloak.author: DeathDark
220498: Armadillo Cloak.text_parsed: The lifegain on this card works exactly the same as Lifelink would.  Any time the creature deals damage (combat, noncombat, deathtouch, trample, double-strike, etc), you gain that much life.  The difference is that Lifelink goes to the creature's controller, not you.  This one still goes to you.  You can use it to negate a powerful creatures' damage, put it on an ally's creature to gain you life for it attacking, or put it on a creature with Lifelink.  As previously mentioned, this ability stacks with Lifelink, though lifelink does not stack with itself.

220498: Armadillo Cloak.author: GrimjawxRULES
220498: Armadillo Cloak.text_parsed:
@fhemo: Do you gain life for the damage that gets through to the defending player by trample? or all the damage the creature deals even if blocked?

Yes and yes, you would gain life in both cases. Trample damage is still dealt by the enchanted creature, not the ability itself, meaning that you would gain life from any damage that "tramples on" to your opponent, and if the enchanted creature is blocked by something that has enough toughness to survive combat, you would still gain life equal to the enchanted creature's power (unless part of or all of the damage was prevented).
In addition, should your creature become blocked with no creature to block it (i.e. Curtain of Light), or the blocker somehow leaves combat (i.e. Unsummon or similar), all of the damage would just "trample on" to your opponent, dealing full damage to them and gaining you the full amount of life. (Note however that damage only continues "tramples on" to your opponent this way if your creature has trample. If you Curtain of Light a creature without trample, it deals no damage to the defending player)

220500: Fires of Yavimaya.author: jetzine
220500: Fires of Yavimaya.text_parsed:
WHY THE SAC IS RELEVANT:

Fires was traditionally played in the context of efficient, undercosted, BIG creature threats like Blastoderm ( for 5 power) or Shivan Wurm ( for 7 power). Or cards like Saproling Burst, which net you 12 damage for 5 mana when the tokens have haste.

You're probably thinking that 5 damage on turn 3 followed by 17 on turn 4 will get you there. This is generally the case (or the fix, as it was called), but Fires doesn't always get those kinds of draws. The thing that enables a total shut-out in a strong matchup where the opponent is capable of neutralizing some of these threats quickly is the extra 2 points of damage. It's that extra 2 damage that pushes it over the edge, even if its on a lone Birds of Paradise flying over their team. It's an instant speed ability, and it has the ability to come out of nowhere. It also makes the playing of multiple Fires in the mid-late game a viable thing.

The Fires deck is the ultimate R/G aggro deck in my opinion. It combines brute force with ferocious speed. It's about blowing your opponent out with more damage than they can count early in the game, and that extra 2 points goes the distance. Trust me.

It's an instant speed ability, and it has the ability to come out of nowhere.  It also makes the playing of multiple Fires in the mid-late game a viable thing.

The Fires deck is the ultimate R/G aggro deck in my opinion.  It combines brute force with ferocious speed.  It's about blowing your opponent out with more damage than they can count early in the game, and that extra 2 points goes the distance.  [i]Trust[/i] me.

220501: Heroes' Reunion.author: Pillow676
220501: Heroes' Reunion.text_parsed:
The card that immediately jumps to mind when I see this card is Rest For The Weary. RFTW is normally better, because it gains you one more life, and doesn't require green mana. The place where this card would be better though, is at the end of an opponents turn. If you have extra mana to spend this card gives you three more life if you didn't play a land that turn. The only reason you really would play a land during an opponents turn is if you had a landfall deck, or if you were using Terramorphic Expanse/Evolving Wilds.

In most life gain decks the extra life is better (especially if you play: turn one: Serra Ascendant turn two: Rest For The Weary) but they both are good, cheap ways to gain a substantial amount of life.

220509: Magister Sphinx.author: Rhuyn
220509: Magister Sphinx.text_parsed:
I have a rulings question on this card that I cannot find.

My opponent has 4 Soul Warden's on the field. My Magister Sphinx enters the battlefield. Which card's effect triggers first? Is my opponent at 10 life or 14 life?

Just to be redundant, does Magister Sphinx trigger before the 4 Soul Warden's give my opponent 4 life or after?
220509: Magister Sphinx.text_posted:
I have a rulings question on this card that I cannot find.

My opponent has 4 Soul Warden's on the field. My Magister Sphinx enters the battlefield. Which card's effect triggers first? Is my opponent at 10 life or 14 life?

Just to be redundant, does Magister Sphinx trigger before the 4 Soul Warden's give my opponent 4 life or after?

220509: Magister Sphinx.author: Tynansdtm
220509: Magister Sphinx.text_parsed:
@Rhuyn: From the comprehensive rulebook:
405.3. If an effect puts two or more objects on the stack at the same time, those controlled by the active player are put on lowest, followed by each other player's objects in APNAP order (see rule 101.4). If a player controls more than one of these objects, that player chooses their relative order on the stack.

In other words, you, the active player put your triggers on the stack. Then each non-active player puts their triggers in turn order, in the order of their choosing. That means your opponent will put his triggers on the stack above yours (in any order, but they're all identical). Then your opponent's triggers will resolve first and he'll gain life, then your ability will resolve and set their life total to 10.

220510: Master Transmuter.author: CeremonialBathory
220510: Master Transmuter.text_parsed:
@shocker300 - You could use her to play artifact spells of the color chosen with Iona, yes. Iona only stops you from playing the cards normally, putting them in to play with an ability such as Master Transmuter, Elvish Piper or Mindwrack Liege is still possible.

@ElTaco - Yes. The rule of playing only one land a turn only applies if you play that land as a land. It sounds confusing, but it isn't really. Take for instance fetch lands, like Evolving Wilds. You can play that land, tap it and put another land from your library on the battlefield because you're using its ability to do so.

220510: Master Transmuter.author: Lyoncet
220510: Master Transmuter.text_parsed:
@StagingTheUniverse
"why would anyone use this for a darksteel colossus, when they could use this for a darksteel forge"

Why would you use this for a Darksteel Forge, when you could use this for a Blightsteel Colossus and just win next turn?

I'm surprised that nobody's mentioned another wonderful application of this little gem. Yeah, you can Tinker out your Blightsteel Colossus on turn 5 with no ramp (earlier if you build your deck around it), but a more subtle - and potentially just as useful - use is to protect your artifacts. Naturalize on your Memnarch? Nope, that Memnarch is now a Silver Myr. The Myr doesn't even get Naturalized since the target is no longer on the field. Throwing your horde of small artifact creatures at your opponent's big bruisers? Just tap a couple Transmuters and bounce back whoever gets blocked. On the defensive, return and replay whatever tapped creatures you want to block with, or block and bounce your Memnites before your opponent assigns damage. And since returning the artifact is a cost and playing an artifact is the ability, you can just bounce something and put it back down at the same time and still fizzle the spell.

If you want some mana ramp, just bounce an Ornithopter for Seat of the Synod. And if you want to be really mean, and have the mana for it (easy with Vedalken Engineer or Etherium Sculptor), you could always Font of Mythos as an instant with Shimmer Myr/Leyline of Anticipation, get your draw two, then return it to your hand, netting yourself an artifact on the field and a one-sided draw-2 at instant speed, every turn, for 4U at absolute most. On top of that, you can combo her with a number of cards, like Basalt Monolith or Vedalken Archmage with 0 CMC artifacts, for mana ramp or easy draws. Or you can plop a Gilded Lotus, enchant her with Pemmin's Aura, and start an infinite mana loop. And you can put down a Vedalken Archmage and get an infinite mana and draw loop that you have full control over (something most infinite draw loops don't give you).

And of course since she can use her own ability on herself, after summoning sickness passes, there's essentially no way anyone can kill her if she's untapped and you have one blue mana. This card would be a 5/5 even if just for the ability to drop your fatties for U, add in the protection, nigh invulnerability, and combo potential for a slim, splashable casting cost and you've got a complete monster.

220510: Master Transmuter.author: Ancestral_Forget
220510: Master Transmuter.text_parsed:
This card is probably the most powerful creature in the game.

If they try to kill another artifact, she very calmly flickers that artifact back to your hand and plays it again. And if you don't want to play it again, no heat, you can play a different artifact or just nothing at all.
If they try to kill her, she very calmly flickers herself back to your hand and plays herself again. And of course she doesn't need to come out, you can play a different artifact or just nothing at all.
If they try to kill her again, she gets mad and puts out a draco. Then she calmly watches from your hand, unharmed, while draco enjoys his meal.

220510: Master Transmuter.author: GrimjawxRULES
220510: Master Transmuter.text_parsed:
@Manite: Blew my mind. I use this card all the time in EDH but never noticed it until now.

With regards to the card, Master Transmuter is downright insane. She abuses artifacts with powerful enters-the-battlefield abilities, cheats stuff onto the battlefield at instant speed, and can even return herself in response to removal. Even better, if she's targeted by spot removal you can return her to your hand and put her onto the battlefield again with her own ability, countering the spot removal in the process.

Such a strong card, not to forget highly splash-able with only 1 colored mana symbol in its casting cost. At this point Master Transmuter's only weakness is really the fact that she doesn't have haste, but even that can be solved with (you guessed it) artifacts - specifically stuff like Thousand-Year Elixir and/or Lightning Greaves.
Play this card in any commander deck that deals with artifacts, and any regular 60-card artifact that isn't Affinity. 5/5 all day every day.

220511: Path to Exile.author: Kryptnyt

the most interesting thing about this card, to me, is the way it shames Rampant Growth when played in most Green/White decks. path your plant token at instant speed on the opponents end step for some sweet surprise land.
Yeah, I'd use Swords over this almost all of the time in a serious deck; this often helps the opponent more than a utility creature will, adjusting the saturation of their deck in a favorable manner to them, getting them a land into play, etc.
That is to say, its not bad if you play it after they use Enlightened Tutor or imperial seal or the like, forcing them to bypass the land in order to not shuffle and negating the drawback. Also much better on your last turn of aggro, obviously.

220511: Path to Exile.author: Atali
220511: Path to Exile.text_parsed:
I don't know why everyone keeps bringing up the strength disparity between black removal and white removal. White has been a very strong removal color since the very beginning (Wrath of God, Swords to Plowshares, Balance) and has had a lot of noncreature removal as well (Armageddon, Disenchant). Granted, much of its strongest removal were the board-clearing kind, but the precedent is there.

That said, Path to Exile is too powerful, it puts nearly everything else to shame with its effect vs cost ratio, and can be used for mana acceleration in a pinch. This should probably have been a sorcery.

I gave 4.5 to both.

220511: Path to Exile.author: Gabriel422
220511: Path to Exile.text_parsed:
Printing anything that you can compare reasonably with Swords to Plowshares is a mistake, as there's no longer any point in playing 6+ cost creatures, without some wacky ways to dodge a removal. While you could argue that people shouldn't play with those creatures in the first place, but I believe it's a mistake when you own a card as awesome as Akroma and you never want to play her, knowing fully that she isn't even getting the first 6 damage in. Super-efficient removal lay extreme emphasis on keywords like Shroud, while making any other keyword and the p/t stats largely irrevelent on a huge creature. Erasing the meaningfulness of so many parameters that make different cards unique -- just about as dumb as Umezawa's Jitte making exactly what creatures you play largely unimportant.

I wish they had learned better when they stopped printing Swords in 5th edition.

Why are there so many nubz in here? White had Swords to Plowshares in *alpha*. Claiming white doesn't do removal is ignorance of the game as a whole IMO. They do TONS of mass removal, and have plenty of destruction/exile action.

Just look up Exile Target Creature in white and you'll find several variants on these forms of cards. Just because you disagree and feel that white doesn't/shouldn't do it doesn't mean it doesn't do it. Unmake, Exile, Path to Exile, Reciprocate, Devouring Light, Excise...

Further, white has target sacrifices and similar as well.

5/5, stop whining.

220511: Path to Exile.author: HolyCause
220511: Path to Exile.text_parsed:
I agree that white is about removal through exile and that this card is extremely flavourful. That being said, this card is far, far too powerful. If there was a restriction that only your opponents could mana ramp, that would be fine - but as it stands, this card is very unfun to play against.

The Swords to Plowshares argument is a red herring; that card was quite ridiculous. And if you haven't noticed, Alpha had a lot of balance issues (like any game system). That's like saying blue should get a near functional reprint of Ancestral Recall: some cards deserve to die and be improved upon to make the game not so tedious.

220511: Path to Exile.author: sarroth
220511: Path to Exile.text_parsed:
@blurrymadness: I love this card and Swords to Plowshares, but saying that a color did something since Alpha is not the best argument, given how the colors had vague shapes back then but aren't completely the same as now. Blue being able to blow up stuff just because it was Red for instance? That's definitely out of color for what we'd consider now.

Like I said, I love this card. White should have good removal. Black should have the best, then White. Red will have the weakest removal because it's damaged-based, but Red should also be given the most cards that can be aimed at the player as well, which gives it its own versatility.

I agree with Gabriel422 about cheap removal discouraging powerful, high costed creatures (and I love Akroma, so I'd like to play her), but they're also needed to keep the game in check in terms of creature power level. Creatures are more powerful now than they used to be, and I don't know how much we should be avoiding powerful removal just let creatures roam free.

220512: Volcanic Fallout.author: igniteice
220512: Volcanic Fallout.text_parsed:
Volcanic Fallout is the best at what it does, simple as that. It can find a use even when it doesn't come up against mass token decks or counter decks. Sure it's ineffective at a certain point (protection from red, multiple intangible virtues out, creatures that want to be killed, etc.), but then all cards are. When it does shine though, it makes its mark. In a minority of situations, Slagstorm is going to be better (you need to do 3 damage to every creature instead of 2, or you need only to damage players). Otherwise, the instant speed on this is far superior. And icing on the cake? You can redirect the damage to planeswalkers.

(And if you want to get around creatures with protection abilities and 3+ toughness, Sudden Spoiling.)

220515: Reassembling Skeleton.author: Spet
220515: Reassembling Skeleton.text_parsed:
I agree with infernox10, although I do think that this is strictly better than Drudge Skeletons any day of the week. If you play Drudge Skeletons on turn two, you're taking a huge risk if someone were to kill it, because you can't pay the reg cost. This card is way more versatile and you can have a buttload of fun with it. For example:

1. You are forced to discard a card. Smile, and put this in your graveyard.
2. You have this in play and your opponent plays Gatekeeper of Malakir. Sacrifice this and take him back whenever you feel like it.
3. You play against a nasty Eldrazi deck. This is probably one of the best cards that can deal with Annihilator.
4. Devour. You get the point.

And much more. All in all, a great card.

4.5/5

220518: Bituminous Blast.author: AXER
220518: Bituminous Blast.text_parsed:
How do I tell this site to add something to the rulings:

It seems people think Cascade means you may basically cast any card with lower CMC in your library. They word "may" refers to casting the card only if you want to; not that if you don't want to, then you may keep exiling cards until another card with meeting criteria is revealed. Cascade rulings never say this!
In Alara, MTG states that Cascade grants you a free spell but you DON'T KNOW what's it's going to be! If you keep exiling cards after the first available free spell is revealed, then essentially this contradicts MTG's statement because you would pretty much KNOW which spell you would get!
The reason the rulings say "may" is because for example the spell may have an ability you do not desire (for instance, "destroy all creatures"); the purpose of "may" is not "or keep on searching."

If you decide not to play the first nonland card revealed with lower CMC, then Cascade is completed. Put all the exiled cards on the bottom of your library in a random order and you got to play no free spell.

This ability is not among the MTG's newest. Back then, MTG didn't come up with cards that were "just too easy" and then gave them the excuse that... "oh, but it's mythic rare."

220518: Bituminous Blast.author: OpeeFomenom
220518: Bituminous Blast.text_parsed: I'm sorry, but you aren't going to just add things to the ruling like that. It doesn't need to be there, for the sole reason that if they were to add a new ruling every time some beginner tried to do something with a card that the card doesn't say it does, cards would be covered in rulings. Cards do what they say they do. Period. Sometimes it's not clear due to being wordy, or, more commonly what they do while another card is doing something else might also not be clear. That's when a ruling is necessary.

220519: Colossal Might.author: NoobOfLore
220519: Colossal Might.text_parsed:
:+3/+3 until end of turn.

:+1/-1 and trample until the end of turn. Given, Tramples isn't really a red ability, but +1/-1 at instant speed deserves some sort of benefit. It would probably be first strike if it wasn't for green interfering.
Flowstone has taught us that = +1/-1 as a repeatable ability, and putting a trait on an instant generally requires a small boost to make up for the lack of repeatability.
I mean, you don't see creatures walking around with :This creature gets +3/+3

Seems pretty fair to me. Based, of course, on the idea that Giant Growth is fair.

@Hoonster:
It makes more sense if you take into account the difficulty of paying two different types of mana. That, and "+1/-1" as a one-off ability really shouldn't constitute a whole mana by itself. So, the red mana squeezes in both +1/-1 and trample, seeing as neither of them warrant a whole mana by themselves, and then accommodate for consolidating cards together by the difficulty of having two different colored mana in the cost.
That, and :+1/-1 isn't a card by itself, so we're not just mashing cards together and saying its fair(Although it has been done before).

220522: Mistvein Borderpost.author: Bazooka99
220522: Mistvein Borderpost.text_parsed:
Why is this rated so low? For starters, it's a dual land whose only real requirement is that you have a basic land in play or in your hand (which is a perfectly reasonable requirement in many formats). If that were all, maybe it would deserve a rating this low. But the borderpost

- Can be used as an overcosted Rampant Growth instead of being played "as a land drop", offering the option for mana accel.
- Counts as an artifact, to pump up Master of Etherium fast or act as an easy enabler for Master Transmuter.
- Is both a blue and black permanent. Bloom Tender anyone?
Turn 1: Forest, bounce for Fieldmist Borderpost
Turn 2: Forest, Bloom Tender
Turn 3: Bounce Forest for Veinfire Borderpost and replay. Now find something to do with your 7 mana, which includes all 5 colors.
- Can be cheated into play with Etherium Sculptor, like a free land drop.
- Enables you to produce mana from a land twice (by bouncing it and replaying). You could play Grand Abolisher with only one plains available.
- Are common/easy to obtain. No paying $10 for a playset of what should be a utility card.

It might not be as mana-efficient, but no dual land comes close to this kind of versatility.

220527: Leonin Abunas.author: scumbling1
220527: Leonin Abunas.text_parsed:
Old Tooth and Nail decks use to run this guy to tutor up along side Platinum Angel; The opponent would have to remove both creatures to win the game. Then, they soon realized that if they just ran two Platinum Angels the opponent would have the same requirements to win, but in a shorter time frame.

The deck moved on to other combinations of creatures, but there's a principle behind the Abunas / Angel anecdote: it's better to just run more threats than cards that protect your other threats. Your Platinum Angel (or whatever) will always beat up opponents without the help of anything else. Leonin Abunas is fairly pointless if you don't have other artifacts to protect, and is therefore less consistent. Additionally, having more Angels gives you more power to end the game quicker, giving the opponent less time to draw a removal spell to stop you. You can castle yourself in under the effects of shroud, but you still need to eventually win the game. Winning faster is just as valid a way of reducing harm to yourself.

220528: Lightning Greaves.author: HaseoYamazaki
220528: Lightning Greaves.text_parsed:
while the affects are cost of this card are great, the shroud affect has one serious drawback,
The official rules for shroud are as follows:
702.16. Shroud
702.16a Shroud is a static ability. "Shroud" means "This permanent or player can't be the target of spells or abilities."

meaning you can't target the equipped creature with even you're own spells or abilities that can directly target it. That includes other equipment.

220528: Lightning Greaves.author: Equinox523
220528: Lightning Greaves.text_parsed:
Aside from all of the excellent suggestions other users have made, I'd like to also mention how great these shoes are in reanimator decks. Not only does it make your newly risen creatures immune to spells, but also gives them the ability to attack immediately. Combine this with the innate "come into play" abilities of many modern fatties, and you could easily change board position greatly. Think about it:

Unearth a Cosmic Larva and slap Lightning Greaves on. Swing for 7 with trample.

Zombify Arcanis the Omnipotent and slap on the shoes for a 3 card tap.

Cast Dread Return on Nicol Bolas, slap on a Lightning Greaves and hit for 7 in the air with massive discard.

The possibilities are endless, and the fact that this is both cheap (to equip and cast) and colorless, and not even a rare, makes this card amazing.

220528: Lightning Greaves.author: TheMurderousKitten
220528: Lightning Greaves.text_parsed:
@Kryptnyt: This card doesn't have any effect on Wrath of God, since Wrath does not target. Even creatures with shroud die to Wrath and similar board-wipes.

@HaseoYamazaki: The "drawback" of this card isn't as big of a deal as you seem to think. No, you cannot target the equipped creature with your own spells or equipment, but as long as you have at least one other creature in play, you can simply shift the Greaves to the other creature for free, do whatever you need to on the first creature, then shift the Greaves back to it when you are done. It leaves the creature vulnerable to instant removal while you do it, but that's not that big of a drawback in my book. Just wait until your opponent is tapped out before doing it.
220528: Lightning Greaves.text_posted:
@Kryptnyt:  This card doesn't have any effect on [autocard]Wrath of God[/autocard], since Wrath does not target.  Even creatures with shroud die to Wrath and similar board-wipes.

@HaseoYamazaki:  The "drawback" of this card isn't as big of a deal as you seem to think.  No, you cannot target the equipped creature with your own spells or equipment, but as long as you have at least one other creature in play, you can simply shift the Greaves to the other creature for free, do whatever you need to on the first creature, then shift the Greaves back to it when you are done.  It leaves the creature vulnerable to instant removal while you do it, but that's not that big of a drawback in my book.  Just wait until your opponent is tapped out before doing it.

220528: Lightning Greaves.author: Kryptnyt
220528: Lightning Greaves.text_parsed:
Cards that help out creature decks are always ok in my book. Wrath of God needs a weakness, and shatter needs a job.
@TheMurderousKitten
That's not exactly where I was going with that. Say you have a few creatures in play and a lightning greaves. You're pressuring your opponent, he's got a few creatures as well, and he wraths. Well, feel free to pop in a creature and swing in through his conveniently empty board.
Also, haste increases the damage output of your creatures. You want to squeeze every ounce of value out of the bastards that you can. The shroud on greaves is nice, its true, but the haste is what I like most.

220529: March of the Machines.author: tcollins
220529: March of the Machines.text_parsed:
Artscrafter,

Very neat idea! However the Mindslaver tokens that are popped out by Mimic Vat will have a converted mana cost of 0 instead of 6 because they are tokens. As such, the token will enter play as a 0/0 creature (because of March of the Machines) and will immediately be put into the graveyard as a state-based effect. There are tonnes of crazy combos with this card but i think one of the simplest and most efficient early game is with Darksteel Ingot; a 3/3 indestructible creature that can tap for mana for {3}? Yes please!

220529: March of the Machines.author: Artscrafter
220529: March of the Machines.text_parsed:
This has some interesting effects with some of the stuff in Scars.
For one thing, it gives Mimic Vat all the versatility of Prototype Portal as long as you can play and sac the artifact you want to imprint.

Imagine this play.
Turn 1: Island.
Turn 2: Island, Etherium Sculptor
Turn 3: Island, Grand Architect
Turn 4: Tap the sculptor, architect, and 3 lands to play Mindslaver and Mimic Vat. (Optionally drop an island and hold for Turn Aside vs. removal.)
Turn 5: Play a land if you didn't on turn 4. Play March of the Machines. Tap the sculptor and the architect for mana, use it to pop the Mindslaver. Imprint it to Mimic Vat.
Turn 6+: Solitaire mode!

(Aside: I know you can just use Prototype Portal to recur Mindslaver, but this lets you do an activation a turn for instead of , and if you happen to find a Training Grounds this makes it cost .)

@tcollins: Normally, tokens would have a CMC of 0. But if a token is a copy of another object, it has the CMC of the copied object because mana cost is a copiable value. So token copies of Mindslaver will have a CMC of 6 and thus be 6/6 creatures with this out until you pop them.

@heavilymedicated: You couldn't imprint Soul Foundry onto Soul Foundry because that specifically looks for a "creature card" in your hand. March doesn't change the types of cards that aren't on the battlefield. You can, however, imprint one Prototype Portal onto another (without needing March to do it) or imprint a Soul Foundry onto a Portal.

220529: March of the Machines.author: Lyoncet
220529: March of the Machines.text_parsed:
For those talking about the Mycosynth Lattice and Master of Etherium combo for a one-sided Armageddon, why not just run the Lattice with Karn, Silver Golem. Yeah, you have to use a few mana to activate Karn's ability, but you cut it from a 3-card combo to just 2. You don't even need to run blue that way.

Sure, if you do it the first way you could use all three to wipe your opponent's lands and then swing with your lands as 1/1s, but wouldn't it be better just to add Tezzeret the Seeker to the Karn/Lattice combo and make all your lands (again, with three cards) 5/5s instead?

Don't get me wrong; this is a very good card, although you need to work to protect your Seat of the Synod/Everflowing Chalice/Chimeric Mass etc. if you're running those. But combos that force you to sit on some of the cards until you get the right draw are usually best avoided, especially when you can do the same thing by other (easier) means.

220529: March of the Machines.text_parsed:
Time to get creative! What's so awesome about this card is how it can create vastly different combos.

I run it in a deck where I use it with stuff like Liquimetal Coating and Dross Scorpion to wipe out opponents' lands amongst other things. Quick way to lose friends too.

A buddy of mine uses it in an entirely different deck where he turns things like Spine of Ish Sah into massive creatures as well as using Training Grounds and Heartstone to lower the cost on activated abilities of his animated artifacts so he can do stuff like simply tap Tower of Murmurs to deck you out in a few turns.

220530: Sun Droplet.author: Lyoncet
220530: Sun Droplet.text_parsed:
@Kryptnyt
"1 per upkeep.
Not just your upkeep though. It includes opponent's upkeeps, so its inclusion in Archenemy was sound."

I thought so too. Then I looked up the rules, and found that the Heroes in Archenemy all share one turn. That means 1 upkeep phase, 1 untap phase, etc., so this card doesn't give you more benefit in that setting (same is true in Two-Headed Ogre according to errata). Still works in normal multiplayer though. It's a shame, too. This card, which isn't that great on its own, really could have used that extra niche benefit.

220530: Sun Droplet.author: AssKickingBoots
220530: Sun Droplet.text_parsed:
It would be kind of funny to play this in a troll themed deck. Not good, just funny.

Still, unless you're playing a big multiplayer against morons that attack every opportunity, especially with small creatures (a tactic I call Llanowaring you to death), then there isn't much advantage to this card. Any well constructed creature heavy deck will crush you too quickly for it to matter, this doesn't do anything against life loss, is worthless against Infect (I'd assume you'd still get the counters on Sun Droplet, but also the poison counters), so much other than a really bad burn deck I don't what this beats.

Somebody mentioned the old Painlands like Brushland as a use for them, but there are far better ways to use them, like with Tamanoa (though that's 3 different specific mana). Sure, with multiple copies of Sun Droplet you could potentially gain life for each use of painlands, but Tamanoa DOES gain you life with multiple copies.

So I met some guys the other day at my local shop, and they laughed when I said that Memnarch was probably the most broken General in EDH. They insisted that mono green was more powerful, so in about an hour with the help of the shop owner (for cards I didn't have) and my brother, I threw together a mono blue deck with this guy as the General. Fairly early in (can't remember which turn it was) I had Training Grounds down, and used Bribery to grab his Mana Reflection. Dropping Memnarch the next turn and grabbing his Seedborn Muse. I felt a little bad when his last resistance came in the form of Beast Within, and I sent it back at his lands with Spelljack, only to steal the token next turn with Memnarch.

Yeah, this guy is pretty nasty in EDH. That said, it was pretty funny seeing how ***ed they were getting.

220532: Memnarch.author: Platinum_Dragon_Tamer
220532: Memnarch.text_parsed:
@Kragash and @ All who are confused

A card's colo is not a card's "color identity." A card's color is determined by the mana symbols in its casting cost. A card's color identity is determined by the mana symbols found anywhere on the card.

For example: Memnarch is colorless, but has a blue color identity, because it has blue mana symbols.

Thunderscape Battlemage's color is red, but its color identity is red, green, and black.

So Memnarch can be a general in a blue EDH deck.
Thelon of Havenwood can be the general of a black and green deck.

Color identity is a new term that was coined by the creators of EDH.

I hope that clears everything up for those confused by the term "color identity."
220532: Memnarch.text_posted:
@Kragash and @ All who are confused

 A card's [b]colo[/b] is not a card's "[i]color identity[/i]." A card's [b]color[/b] is determined by [b]the mana symbols in its casting cost[/b]. A card's [i]color identity[/i] is determined by [i]the mana symbols found anywhere on the card. [/i] 

For example: [autocard]Memnarch[/autocard] is [b]colorless[/b], but has a [i]blue[/i] color identity, because it has blue mana symbols.

[autocard]Thunderscape Battlemage[/autocard]'s color is [b]red[/b], but its color identity is [i]red, green, and black[/i].

So Memnarch can be a general in a blue EDH deck.
[autocard]Thelon of Havenwood[/autocard] can be the general of a black and green deck.

Color identity is a new term that was coined by the creators of EDH. 

I hope that clears everything up for those confused by the term "color identity."

I just built a Memnarch EDH deck, and can say that he is one of the strongest generals around.
I mean, at least as a mono-coloured general.

It's obvious to have lots of artifacts in the deck. Obvious artifact support cards like Master Transmuter, Voltaic Key, Darksteel Forge, and Mycosynth Lattice are a sure fit. Darksteel Colossus is a decent addition, just in case you're willing to sacrifice 3 artifacts with Kudoltha Forgemaster.

The obvious problem with a lot of the following cards is that they're expensive. To answer that problem, I have a lot of ": Add to your mana pool" artifacts, like Sol Ring, Thran Dynamo, Mana Crypt, or even Sisay's Ring. You can usually ramp to mana within 4 turns, if you're lucky. Other cards like Semblance Anvil, Cloud Key and Etherium Sculptor can also help you a lot, and their artifact type is rarely a problem.

Although everyone's loving Training Grounds, sometimes Heartstone does the job just as well. It helps with metalcraft (if that matters) and it costs colourless mana, which let me tell you, coloured mana is valuable in this deck.

In conclusion, the deck works very well. The only problem I have is getting blue mana. Originally, I played Urza's lands, but I found that a simple basic Island was a better choice.
On that note, you might want to play Mox Opal, Vedalken Engineer, Silver Myr or Eye of Ramos.

220534: Everflowing Chalice.author: IshubarashI
220534: Everflowing Chalice.text_parsed:
I'm still not 100% sure about this card, it has its advantages, but it's almost like a riddle. If I draw it early game I don't want to use it because I can't get very many charge counters on it, but if I draw it late game I don't want to use it because I'll essentially throw a turn away tapping all my lands to charge it up.

However, from experience, once it's out the extra 2-3 mana you get out of it tends to be very useful. Another way to look at it is a turn 2 mana accelerator, put one charge counter on it then on turn 3 you can drop another land and play something that costs four, something like an Ondu Giant to get another land out and have a decently sized blocker for turn 3.

The card definitely has potential, but I can't make a solid judgment on it. So, I'll give it a 3/5

Much of this card's power is related to coming into play untapped. You only lose x mana the turn you play it, where x is the number of counters. There are many turn 3's and turn 5's where you want to play a 2 drop or a 3 drop. In general you should wait for a turn that you can play it efficiently. Better 1 counter and a creature than 2 counters and a wasted turn.

Increase your odds of of playing efficiently by putting artifacts that cost or in the deck, for example:
Bonesplitter, Flayer Husk, Arcbound Worker, Arcbound Stinger, Contagion Clasp, Porcelain Legionnaire and Vault Skirge.

220534: Everflowing Chalice.author: xBattlemagex
220534: Everflowing Chalice.text_parsed:
This is a pretty good card and its unfortunate how people over look it wanting it to be some type of super ramp card allowing super huge spells to be cast. The reason why it received so much play is that it allowed decks that dont run any type of ramp to get a nice acceleration of mana without any huge draw backs.

Reasons its a good card

-There a no clear disadvantages of running 2-3 in a deck

- It becomes better than most ramp spells on turn 4

- Its not a creature, the are thousands of ways to kill off creatures and they are usually main boarded so i would think twice about replacing this with a 2/2 myr wouldnt be the best idea if you looking for ramp.

220536: Lodestone Golem.author: kiseki

220542: Rakdos Guildmage.author: GrimjawxRULES
220542: Rakdos Guildmage.text_parsed:
@RobinHood3000: but that's what they're doing with so many other cards. 5/5 Dragon tokens with flying, or tokens for Dragon Broodmother. Or how about the Golem token for use with Stone Idol Trap?

Anyway, I don't really care if they print tokens or not. It seems like a waste of cardboard if you ask me, unless people are actually buying boosters to get sufficient amounts of a specific token card. I still use glass beads, and dices to keep track of tokens, as they require a lot less space. But if Wizards intend to keep on producing token cards, then I agree with A3Kitsune on the point that they should make new tokens for old reprints that don't have them yet. By the way, A3Kitsune, they might have made those tokens once. I think I might have seen them somewhere, but I could be mistaken.

On topic (discussing the card), it's pretty decent at what it does. It's Rakdos, so having 0 cards in hand shouldn't really be a problem (that's the theory at least). Also, its first ability can act as a discard outlet with some amount of creature killing stuck to it. You can discard some powerful creature (Rakdos the Defiler, for example?), kill a small threat, and then reanimate your creature with something like, say Torrent of Souls on your next turn.
The second ability is decent when you haven't got any cards in hand and just have a lot of mana to spare, which makes perfect sense since Rakdos, again, is all about having around 0 cards in hand. The token also gets a significant boost when you've got Anthem of Rakdos on the battlefield, especially if you've got no cards in hand (which is probably why you're using its ability in the first place).

Synergy my friends; it's all about the synergy ;)
This card ain't half bad once you realize its potentials with the right cards. And if nothing else, it's still a 2/2 for 2 mana with powerful creature types - Shaman, which goes well in red decks (think Rage Forger, Lightning Crafter), and Zombie, which goes well in ... well, Zombie decks obviously. The discard ability may even matter more in Zombie decks with reanimation - you should consider it if you think Withered Wretch is good.

I'd normally give it 3.5/5, but I want to give it 4/5 instead because it's usable in so many ways. It might not be the card that wins the game by itself, but it more than makes up for it in terms of fun and interaction.

220542: Rakdos Guildmage.author: leomistico
220542: Rakdos Guildmage.text_parsed:
Really? People complaining that a 2/2 for CMC2, with 2 (TWO!) revelant abilities, is bad?
Do you really want the abilities to cost less? Really? Repeteable removal and/or creature that can attack without fear to lose them for 4 each are bad? Really?
If you didn't noticed it, you can play the token ability at the end of the opponent's turn, and the Goblin wouldn't leave the Field until your next end step. So you can untap and attack with it and have mana open to plat the black ability in case, or to put another token into play and attack with 2 tokens!
This card deserves at least a 4/5...

However, I proxied tokens for Call the Skybreaker (the original are too ugly and didn't own them) and Urza's Factory. I used Magic Set Editor, went to print them in a shop and glued them in common Magic cards that I have more than enough! Then, I put them in unused or broken sleeves to keep then nice. Since you can choose the art to put on them, you can do them as pretty as you want, with much more satisfaction...!

220544: Krosan Verge.author: DarthParallax
220544: Krosan Verge.text_parsed:
This is to Harrow exactly what Verdant Catacombs @co. are to Rampant Growth.

While the tempo is somewhat of a turn-off for me, and I would generally rather work with Verdant Catacombs' friends over any of the other three, if you are playing a deck that doesn't worry about that tempo (say, any Commander deck), this is undoubtedly a great card.

raptorjesus, this is a land, not a spell. Yes, it requires mana to 'use', but it 'drops' for 0. Think of it like a Memnite with an activated ability or something. Also lands have inherent evasion from darn near anything you are likely to see except the tippy top of the destruction-effects of the game.

(Ghost Quarter, Tectonic Edge, Wasteland, and Strip Mine are the only lands that do it. Spells that destroy lands generally aren't good enough anymore compared to what can be done for that amount of mana nowadays. Creature effects that blast the hell out of you (Phyrexian Obliterator, Eldrazi, etc.) are at once both popular and hard to acquire, so I can't really be sure how common they are for you.)

Evasion IMO goes something like this:

1) Hexproof
2) Shroud
3) Protection
4) card type- Land

maybe that's an exaggeration, but if so it's not a huge one.

If you're curious, the flavor is similar to Ghitu Encampment, except even a bit deeper.

These monks live in their monasteries, somewhere peaceful. In times of war they come out (and are quite skilled at combat; think of fantasy monk archtypes.) The "times of war" vs. "times of peace" thing comes from Threshold (7 things are in your graveyard, representing dead things, war spells, whatever..) and thus when he's called upon to defend his monastery, he will.

Also note that a church is somewhat revolving around it's priest, the last bit of flavor may just be that when he dies, so does his church.



..it's not an animated church..
